Nick Conklin.Action: Confidently places a large bet in an illegal high-stakes card game despite the risk.
Wears an ill-fitting, outdated tuxedo and appears indifferent to his appearance.
Compliments the debutante with 'Very nice, Barbie.'
Tells the debutante and her boyfriend to go home, indicating he is done playing.
Attempts to offer advice to the boyfriend ('I'm offering you the benefit of my experience').
Hesitates before calling the debutante's bet, then calls.
Loses the hand with Jacks and tens, showing a lack of winning cards.
Advises the debutante's boyfriend to leave, indicating confidence and experience.
Engages calmly with the debutante and boyfriend despite their taunts.
Does not escalate conflict when Charlie pushes the debutante, showing restraint.
Calmly toasts with Charlie before raid, showing composure and camaraderie.
Shouts 'SHUT THE HELL UP, GODDAMNIT!' to quiet the crowd during raid.
Softens tone and defers to Asst. D.A. Patty Zachara after initial command.
Shrugs and spreads hands when catching Debutante's smile, showing resigned acceptance.
Calmly toasts with Charlie amid chaos, maintaining composure.
Quickly reveals police badge to assert authority during raid.
Commands noisy crowd to quiet down effectively with a loud outburst.
Expresses desire to finish quickly and go home, showing practical focus.
Shrugs and accepts situation with a resigned gesture after catching Debutante's eye.
Follows Cavello immediately after he bolts and jumps through a window, showing commitment to the chase.
Responds to Charlie's encouragement with a simple 'Thanks' and leaves without further interaction.
Immediately follows Cavello through the window without hesitation.
Chases Cavello but falls behind due to being outpaced and short of breath.
Maintains composure after the chase, acknowledges effort with a sigh and a comment.
Glowers at himself in the mirror, showing self-awareness and reflection.
Decides to leave promptly after the incident, possibly indicating resignation or acceptance.
Grabs Charlie's foot playfully when noticing his ankle holster, showing a teasing, informal interaction.
Advises Charlie to get rid of his non-regulation gun for practical reasons, showing concern for his safety.
Points out shaving cream on Charlie's ear before leaving, a small but friendly and attentive gesture.
Uses a somewhat harsh metaphor about stopping someone with a Beretta 32, indicating a tough, no-nonsense attitude.
Identifies Ronnie Cavello and his connections quickly, showing knowledge of the criminal network.
Attempts to kick-start a poorly maintained motorcycle held together with tape and baling wire, demonstrating resourcefulness despite suboptimal equipment.
Notices Charlie's ankle holster and immediately disarms him, enforcing regulations and emphasizing practical effectiveness of weapons.
Critiques Charlie's non-regulation weapon and insists on its removal, showing confidence and understanding of proper police procedure.
Points out a trivial detail (shaving cream on Charlie's ear) before heading out, indicating attention to detail and a lighthearted confidence.
Looks at his own neglected house and quickly leaves, showing avoidance.
Engages in light, friendly banter with Connie at the diner.
Shares an intimate moment with Connie, showing affection by kissing her.
Reluctantly stops intimacy when interrupted, showing respect for boundaries.
Glides past suburban houses and quickly recognizes his own neglected home, then promptly shoots away without hesitation.
Sits alone in a diner reading the Daily News and engages in casual conversation with Connie, showing social awareness and emotional connection.
Shows reluctance and hesitation when interrupted after an intimate moment, indicating some vulnerability or distraction.
Expresses anger toward Charlie but does not escalate conflict; allows Charlie's explanation to slide.
Shows frustration and anger in private but does not direct hostility toward Connie despite being upset.
Expresses anger and frustration but listens to Charlie's explanation without immediate retaliation.
Dismisses the idea of moving up in the organization as unlikely, showing realistic assessment of his situation.
Does not react impulsively to Connie dumping his clothes and gun, instead slowly turns to face Charlie, indicating controlled behavior.
Warns Charlie seriously not to do anything when bodyguards enter, showing concern and protective caution.
Responds to Charlie's joking about shoes with dead seriousness, indicating a no-nonsense attitude but not warmth.
At ease in a tense environment, recognizes the significance of Frank Abolofia's arrival, and warns Charlie not to act impulsively.
Responds sarcastically and evasively when asked about the Japanese man, showing a lack of insight or unwillingness to speculate.
Dismisses Charlie's suggestion with a rude remark and turns away to resume drinking.
Calmly observes the situation and resumes drinking without panic when the gunfire starts.
Advises Charlie to stay quiet and not interfere, showing awareness of the danger and restraint.
Does not attempt to draw a weapon or take immediate action despite the threat, possibly indicating lack of preparedness or inability to respond effectively.
Squeezes Charlie's hand tightly to reassure him and says 'Saving your life.'
Shouts to control the situation and protect others by ordering everyone to stay put and calling for police.
Bolts out the door leaving Charlie in charge, despite Charlie's nervousness and inexperience.
Squeezes Charlie's hand firmly to reassure him and says 'Saving your life.'
Leaps up immediately after the killers leave, pulling his shield and revolver and shouting police commands to control the scene.
Bolts out the door to pursue the killers, showing decisiveness and initiative.
Follows the fleeing suspect on foot, reloading as he runs, showing commitment to duty and protection of others.
Moves cautiously through the alley with gun drawn, nearly shooting a junkie who steps out unexpectedly.
Immediately threatens and kicks Kobo without attempting communication or de-escalation.
Keeps his gun fixed on Kobo and uses force quickly.
Despite being badly beaten, does not retaliate with excessive violence beyond self-defense.
Commands Kobo to get on the ground immediately, attempts to cuff him, and keeps his gun fixed on the suspect.
Underestimates Kobo's speed and fighting ability, resulting in being repeatedly beaten and injured.
Despite being badly beaten and bleeding, Nick gets back up and continues to engage Kobo.
Fails to anticipate or prevent Kobo from pulling a concealed weapon (shuto) and nearly being stabbed.
Lets Charlie's critical look slide without confrontation.
Responds curtly to Capt. Oliver's sarcastic remark.
Maintains focus on mechanical work despite physical pain and injuries.
Snaps a ratchet while working on the motorcycle.
Confidently estimates the size of the drug package and identifies the single perpetrator.
Lets a colleague's critical look slide without confrontation.
Addresses Charlie by name, showing recognition and engagement.

Listens and processes complex information about the Japanese killer and diplomatic complications.

Engages in a tense exchange with Oliver, standing up for himself confidently.
Expresses sour mood and reluctance about the trip, showing emotional resistance but not incompetence.
Dismisses Charlie's plan to extend the trip by faking illness, indicating practical judgment and refusal to engage in unprofessional behavior.
Smiles at Charlie's teasing, shows some tolerance for his partner's behavior.
Tells Charlie to 'shut-up' when he is teasing Kobo.
Responds to Charlie's question about being a good partner with a lighthearted comment and tries to avoid further talk.
Does not engage deeply with Charlie's sincere concern about loyalty and protection.
Responds to Charlie's teasing with a calm, controlled 'Shut-up, Charlie,' showing restraint and confidence.

Avoids engaging in conversation with Charlie by shutting his eyes and giving short answers, showing emotional control but possibly avoiding conflict or deeper communication.
Admits to past mistakes and the social consequences he faces, showing vulnerability and honesty to Charlie.

Grabs Charlie by the arm to move him through customs line.
Refuses to bow out of cultural respect but later concedes 'In Rome, I'll bow.'
Urgently tries to alert others that Kobo is their prisoner and protests their arrest, showing concern for justice and his partner.

Fails to realize the setup and is outsmarted by the prisoner Kobo, resulting in losing custody of him.
Attempts to assert authority and regain control by calling out to customs inspectors and requesting an Identi-Kit description.
Shows frustration and impatience with Inspector Ohashi's uncooperative behavior, but does not escalate or lose composure.

Refuses to take the blame for incompetence, asserting his position firmly.

Argues logically and confidently with Ohashi about security failures, showing understanding of the situation.
Insists on getting a gun and the best detective, demonstrating assertiveness and awareness of his needs.
Refuses to take the blame for the failure, showing confidence and unwillingness to be scapegoated.

Acknowledges Charlie's correct guess about the building location, giving credit and showing cooperation.
Turns the door handle and finds the apartment unlocked, showing initiative and practical problem-solving.

Grabs Joyce's arm and refuses to let go despite her protests, demonstrating poor interpersonal skills and potential recklessness.
Watches Joyce's taxi until it is out of sight before heading inside, indicating caution and situational awareness.
Decides to wake Sugai up despite Sugai being asleep and Ich vigilantly awake with a gun, showing awareness of the situation and taking initiative.
Lies in wait on the balcony with gun ready, successfully intercepts and incapacitates Kobo by slamming his head with the butt of his gun, then drags him inside.
Acts decisively and effectively during a violent confrontation, showing tactical awareness and physical capability.
Stands silently over bound Kobo, then drops spare change in front of him, mirroring Kobo's earlier gesture.
Intervenes verbally to insist that Kobo should be tried by a court before any punishment, asserting ownership and protection over him.
Intervenes verbally to stop Sugai from killing Kobo immediately, insisting on a court conviction first.
Uses a symbolic gesture by dropping coins in front of Kobo, mirroring Kobo's earlier action, showing awareness and psychological insight.
Does not physically intervene to stop the violence, only stands silently above Kobo initially.
Offers Ich a drink after a long abstinence, to share a moment of camaraderie.
Encourages Ich by telling him he did great.
Dismisses Kobo's cynical view of society with a curt remark.
Offers Ich a drink and encourages him, showing social tact and emotional intelligence to support his partner.
Responds calmly and confidently to Sugai's threat, indicating awareness of the stakes and maintaining composure.
Makes a dismissive comment to Kobo about the cultural observations, showing some world-weariness but also confidence in his own experience.
Helps the drunken Salaryman up after he stumbles on him.
Hesitates before unlocking the cuffs to free Joyce, showing reluctance but ultimately complies.
Ignores Kobo's threat and the gravity of the situation, showing detachment.
Helps the drunken Salaryman up without hesitation, showing calmness and presence of mind.
Hesitates before unlocking the cuffs despite the threat, indicating internal conflict or caution.
Acknowledges the difficulty of getting the plate from Sugai, showing realistic understanding of the situation.
Follows Kobo off the train despite the dangerous situation, showing willingness to engage but possibly impulsive.
Not paying much attention during the conversation, possibly missing important cues.
Runs after Kobo and tries to keep sight of the Jaguar, showing concern and urgency.
Shoves past passengers and ignores conductor's angry shouts, showing impatience and disregard for others.
Pleads with Ohashi for help and expresses worry about someone's safety.
Runs after the Jaguar trying to keep it in sight as the train pulls out.
Bursts into the bar car calling for Ichiro, showing urgency and focus.
Shoves past passengers ignoring conductor's angry shouts, showing determination but also recklessness.
Runs out of the train station dodging the crowd, attempting to pursue Kobo.
Gets handcuffed by policemen without successfully explaining or avoiding arrest.
Waits alone in the holding cell for hours, showing patience but no active effort to escape or negotiate.
Pleading with Ohashi for help and trying to get released, but fails to convince him.
Yells loudly for Ohashi, showing concern and urgency.
Sits defeated on the floor, not looking up when someone enters, indicating withdrawal or resignation.
Jokes with Ich about being ready to confront him, showing a friendly, familiar rapport.
Sitting on the floor defeated, not looking up when someone enters, showing a lack of confidence or initiative.
Yelling loudly for Ohashi, showing urgency and emotional investment but no clear strategic action.
Engages in verbal exchange with Ich, indicating readiness to confront and some situational awareness.
Lights a cigarette for Ich, shows empathy by acknowledging Ich's family troubles and sharing his own pain.
Expresses frustration about losing negotiation leverage but remains focused on the situation without blaming Ich.
Questions Ich about the number of men and Joyce, showing focus on gathering critical information.
Recognizes the need for the license plate to negotiate, demonstrating strategic thinking.
Remains calm and composed when the guard scrutinizes them at the airport, successfully passing through security.
Acknowledges Ich's risky action of burning bridges, showing awareness of consequences.
Observes the scene at Sugai's estate and realizes they have no leverage, indicating situational awareness.
Drives while rubbing sleep from his eyes, indicating fatigue but continuing to perform his role.
Lights Ich's cigarette and engages in personal conversation, showing empathy and interpersonal skill.
Thanks Ich for the shuto, showing appreciation.
Engages cooperatively with Ich, listens and responds sincerely.
Rubs out cigarette and presses accelerator without further comment after Ich's wife left, showing emotional restraint but no warmth.
Presses down on the accelerator decisively after a brief moment of reflection.
Accepts the shuto from Ich and tucks it inside his jacket without hesitation.
Leads the approach by opening the car door and climbing out first to confront the situation.
Asks Ich about the purpose of the shuto, showing curiosity and engagement.
Stops to question Ich's confidence about not losing, indicating some caution or doubt.
Swings a hoe to stop an armed biker threatening Ich, effectively protecting his partner.
Mounts the biker's motorcycle and takes the rider's helmet and goggles from Ich, showing resourcefulness and cooperation.
Attacks Kobo aggressively, slamming and kicking him, fighting unfairly.
Tackles Sugai's daughter to wrestle the gun away, slugs her to prevent her from shooting.
Shows concern for Ich by asking if he is all right after Ich is shot.
Tells Joyce to call for help after the shooting.
Pursues Kobo aggressively despite injury, showing determination and resilience.
Avoids collision with truck, indirectly causing the attacking biker to crash.
Mounts the bike and accelerates quickly, attempting to catch Kobo.
Loses control of his bike, fishtails and slides out from under him.
Shoots past the police car despite a scraped and bloody arm, showing determination and skill.
Keeps gaining on Kobo despite difficult weather and terrain, maintaining focus and speed.
Drops back to avoid a knife attack from the pursuing biker, showing quick reflexes and tactical awareness.
Swerves at the last moment to avoid a truck, while the pursuing biker crashes, demonstrating superior situational awareness.
Despite being injured and in pain, struggles to defend himself against Kobo.
Engages in a violent confrontation with Kobo, firing a gun at him.
Charges at high speed toward Kobo in the rain, showing boldness and aggression.
Loses control of his motorcycle on gravel, skids, and goes over the edge of the road.
Despite injury and pain, struggles to retrieve and use his gun under difficult conditions.
Fires a mud-caked gun that explodes in his hand, causing severe injury.
Grabs Kobo's wrist to prevent him from retrieving the plate, then shatters the plate instead of harming Kobo despite having the chance to injure him.
Exhausted, falls back and makes a friendly slashing gesture to Kobo, mirroring a previous sign of understanding between them.
Turns the lights and fans back on after blackout without comment, then quietly leaves.
Watches Ichiro receive medals along with Joyce and Ichiro's wife, showing respectful support.
Engages in light, somewhat teasing conversation with Joyce about her reluctance to join him.
Flips the main switch to restore power to the police headquarters after the blackout, despite being injured and on crutches.
Leaves silently after restoring power without further interaction or explanation.
Expresses willingness to have Joyce visit and spend time together.
Asks Joyce to give a drink to the assistant Chief Inspector, showing consideration for others.
Responds honestly and sincerely to Oliver about not being tempted by money.
Responds calmly and confidently to Capt. Oliver's warning and instructions, showing focus despite injury.
Does not react greedily or impulsively when Oliver mentions the possibility of getting rich by holding on to the plate, indicating clear-headedness and integrity.
Hesitates before eating noodles with his good hand, showing some uncertainty or discomfort.
Helps Ich fasten the strap on his bulletproof vest using one arm despite struggling himself.
Smiles and playfully takes the Frommer's guide out of Ich's pocket and tosses it into the trash.
Offers Ich a shotgun and takes one for himself, showing camaraderie and trust.
Carries heavy bullet proof vests confidently and prepares for the raid despite struggling to get into his vest with one arm, showing determination and focus.
Engages in light banter with Ich, takes the Frommer's guide and tosses it in the trash, indicating confidence and a no-nonsense attitude.
Expresses certainty about success ('We can't lose') which shows confidence but may also suggest overconfidence without evidence.
